constellations_other.name: Webwurlds
constellations_other.description: Jess Johnson and Simon Ward's work is inspired by science fiction and fantasy. Johnson's hand-drawn illustrations are heavily detailed with geometric patterns and incorporate anthropomorphic characters amongst architectural environments in immersive other worlds.

constellations_other.name: One of the first auteurs
constellations_other.description: A progenitor of modern film genres such as sci-fi, psychological thriller and serial killer films decades before such terms were coined, Austrian-born director Fritz Lang also enjoyed the occasional on-screen meta-moment.

links.description: The neon-noir world of Blade Runner drew inspiration from Fritz Lang’s Metropolis, which depicted a city with buildings soaring into the sky and pioneered many of techniques still used to depict sci-fi worlds; large-scale background paintings, miniature sets, animation and forced perspective.

end.title: BioShock
end.brief_description: Set in the Objectivist underwater dystopia of Rapture in the ‘60’s, Bioshock is a first-person shooter with the premise of arming and genetically modifying yourself in order to survive against the city’s resident great minds-turned-maddened anomalies and aid Atlas in his mission to overthrow the city’s cruel ruler, Andrew Ryan.

constellations_other.name: Beacons
constellations_other.description: Tacita Dean's Disappearance at Sea explores the romantic isolation of the lighthouse, a rich setting for stories that artists, filmmakers and game-makers have used to examine the threat and freedom of the sea.

links.description: You might notice some similarities between Metropolis and the underwater city of Rapture where Bioshock is set. Both were inspired by New York art-deco buildings and feature similar architecture and sci-fi city features. Bioshock also proves the creative possibilities of 3D game engines to design impossible worlds.

end.brief_description: The game follows the adventure of a claymation character named Klaymen as he discovers his origins and his purpose in a world made entirely out of clay.

links.description: Isle of Dogs uses the simple principle that scaled-down objects look life-sized filmed up close. Just as Wes Anderson shunned CGI animation, The Neverhood was created when 3D videogames were the next big thing. Instead it used stop-motion animation to create a unique platformer.

constellations_other.name: Princesses, rom-coms and sit-coms
constellations_other.description: Newsreel footage was captured on large, bulky 35mm cameras like the Mitchell Newsreel Camera by operators in the field, but they were also used by film production companies and on TV shows, with some of those involved going on to define different genres.

constellations_other.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_other.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

constellations_other.name: The narrative power of maps
constellations_other.description: Maps are designed to communicate complex information in a clear manner to aid both navigation and wayfinding and knowledge of place.

links.description: With the rise of CGI and 3D engines, unreal creatures and worlds were mostly computer-generated. Practical effects weren’t finished though. Peter Jackson’s first Lord of the Rings film used forced perspective, different sized actors and camera tricks to make the Hobbits look small.
